PERTUZUMAB

  • Indications and doses
  • Drug action
  • Pregnancy

  • Renal impairment

Indications and doses

Treatment of HER2-positive metastatic or locally recurrent unresectable breast cancer in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel, in patients who have not received previous anti-HER2 therapy or chemotherapy (initiated by a specialist),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Drug action

Pertuzumab is a recombinant humanised monoclonal antibody, and acts by inhibiting human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 protein (HER2) dimerisation.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Avoid (toxicity in animal studies).

Most cytotoxic drugs are teratogenic and should not be administered during pregnancy, especially during the first trimester.

Considerable caution is necessary if a pregnant woman presents with cancer requiring chemotherapy, and specialist advice should always be sought.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Caution—no information available.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Caution in severe impairment—no information available.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Anaemia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), arthralgia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), chills (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), constipation (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), cough (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), decreased appetite (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), diarrhoea (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), dizziness (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), dry skin (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), dyspepsia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), dyspnoea (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), febrile neutropenia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), headache (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), increased lacrimation (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), infusion-related reactions (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), insomnia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), left ventricular dysfunction (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), leucopenia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), malaise (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), myalgia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), nail disorder (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), nasopharyngitis (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), neutropenia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), oedema (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), pain (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), paronychia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), peripheral neuropathy (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), pleural effusion (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), pruritus (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), pyrexia (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), rash (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), severe hypersensitivity reactions (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), taste disturbance (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel), upper respiratory-tract infection (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel),

uncommon: Interstitial lung disease (when used in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel),

notKnown: Alopecia, bone-marrow suppression, extravasation, hyperuricaemia, nausea, oral mucositis, thromboembolism, tumour lysis syndrome, vomiting,

Directions for administration

Resuscitation facilities should be available.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Conditions that could impair left ventricular function
  • history of congestive heart failure
  • impaired left ventricular function
  • prior anthracycline exposure
  • radiotherapy to the chest area
  • recent myocardial infarction
  • serious cardiac arrhythmia
  • uncontrolled hypertension

Advice regarding conception and contraception

Exclude pregnancy before treatment with cytotoxic drugs.

Contraceptive advice should be given before cytotoxic therapy begins—ensure effective contraception during and for six months after treatment in women of childbearing potential.

Regimens that do not contain an alkylating drug or procarbazine may have less effect on fertility, but those with an alkylating drug or procarbazine carry the risk of causing permanent male sterility (there is no effect on potency). Pretreatment counselling and consideration of sperm storage may be appropriate. Women are less severely affected, though the span of reproductive life may be shortened by the onset of a premature menopause. No increase in fetal abnormalities or abortion rate has been recorded in patients who remain fertile after cytotoxic chemotherapy.

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Assess for signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (including left ventricular ejection fraction) before and during treatment—consult product literature, and withhold treatment if necessary.

Monitor for febrile neutropenia.

Prepared medicinal forms of PERTUZUMAB

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for infusion
